Only God can be the final judge of someone's eternal fate. Jesus told us not to judge others or we will be judged. 
 
 Also, you are giving Christianity a bad name by your judgmentalism. No one is going to want to go to a heaven full of judgmental people.
Truthsayer

 BRAVO!!!
 
 :p :p :p 
 
 There's a heated debate over in the gay threads about this very thing. These self-proclaimed "rightous" christians are having a hard time wrapping their heads around the fact that their very own bible condemns their acts of judgement much stronger, (or at the least, as strongly) than it condemns the act of homosexuality. While they were casting stones at the "fags" they overlooked their own actions and the level of "sin" it amounted too. So on the "grand measuring scale" of sinners, they are actually lower than the homos in the "eyes of the Lord."
 
 Oh the hypocracy! A laugh a minute. :p Who needs daytime talk TV?
jyoshu

When someone can show me Christian fundamentalists who walk into crowded marketplaces blowing themselves up, or hijack airliners and crash them into buildings killing thousands, I'll accept the idea that extremism is extremism no matter what the religion. Until then, I'll go right on considering Islamic extremism the most dangerous kind.
 
 I don't know why Islamic extremists hate us so, but I do know that at some point we have to accept that the fault is with them and forget this 'we-brought-it-on-ourselves' liberal nonsense.
lord tammerlain

Do you want to bet that if the US (or west in general) left their governments and countries alone that they would leave you alone? That perhaps it is that interference that causes much of the hatred?
 
 Just read up on Iran's history from 1950 onward to get an idea of why Iranians just might dislike the US/UK
Truthsayer

It takes three components to start and maintain any fire. Remove any of the three components and the fire will not exist.
 
 We could remove our support for Isreal and the fire would extinguish.
 
 We could exterminate the people who hate Isreal (Islamaniacs) and the fire would extinguish.
 
 We could disassociate ourselves from the entire Middle East and prohibit anyone from that region to enter our borders and perhaps that would extinguish the fire.
 
 It's a touchy one, no?

 I think you are both right. While we cannot stand in judgment of another persons standing with God, we can and should judge their actions according to the standards of civilized behavior. 
 
 For instance; I believe that what Hitler and Nazi Germany did was evil, plain and simple, no doubt about it. However I will not even attempt to judge Hitler, because for all I know he may have had a stroke of conscience before he died, repented, and asked God for forgiveness. The bible says that God will accept any of us, no matter how sinful if we just sincerely repent and ask for forgiveness. Of course that does not mean we can just go about doing all the same things we used to do.
 
 As far as homosexuals, I do believe it is a sin, but I cannot condemn someone for something that they do not see as sin. Until they are convicted otherwise, it is between them, their conscience and God alone. I can urge them to reconsider, but I can't get on my high horse and condemn them to hell.
Uncle Sam I am

 One of the TV News magazines did a piece right after 911, where they broadcasted an interview with some of the Islamic extremists who were in prison for terroist activity somewhere in the M.E. It was conducted before 911. They said that it was their mission to kill all infidels, because Allah's judgment had come. When asked if they would kill even innocent chidren, they said yes, if their Mullahs told them to. They said that thier Jihad was intended to make the world Islamic because Allah had "had it up to here" (my interpretation) with the infidels.
 
 No change of policy on our part is going to change their idea of the need to kill us. Whatever we have done is already sufficient in their minds to sentence us to death. We need to focus on fighting them instead of understanding them, and trying to compromise with them.
Truthsayer

 Bravo!!!
 
 I'm so glad you decided to stick around. :)
 
 But I am reminded of an old skit on an old TV show called Hee Haw. When the patient told the doctor, "I broke my arm in three places." The doctor tells him, "Well, stay out of those places!"
 
 Perhaps it is too late to reason with the extreme elements of Islam but perhaps we should consider avoiding pouring gasoline on the fire and repeating the mistakes we may have made in the past that assisted in the spawning of these maniacs.
 
 But as to the matters at hand, I have to agree with your statement I have posted above in quotes.

 Thanks Truthsayer. I got off to a bad start on this board, but this has become a pretty good thread after a while. It's also good to see that there is some intelligent life here. I apologize for being so critical.
 
 How do you propose we avoid the mistakes of the past? It seems to me that it may have been easy when we were isolationists (pre WWII), but the world has shrunk and no one country lives in a vacuum anymore. Everything we do, and everything everyone else does, impacts other nations. Especially as long as we are dependant upon the M.E. for oil. That is not something that is going to change overnight.
 
 I also think that as long as we support Israel we will be targeted. But how can we pull our support of the only democracy in the region? And why should we just in order to pacify violent people who will not give us any guarantee that they will be pacified. I think they will always come up with another reason to "kill the infidels."
Truthsayer

Thanks Truthsayer. I got off to a bad start on this board, but this has become a pretty good thread after a while. It's also good to see that there is some intelligent life here. I apologize for being so critical.
 
 How do you propose we avoid the mistakes of the past? It seems to me that it may have been easy when we were isolationists (pre WWII), but the world has shrunk and no one country lives in a vacuum anymore. Everything we do, and everything everyone else does, impacts other nations. Especially as long as we are dependant upon the M.E. for oil. That is not something that is going to change overnight.
 
 I also think that as long as we support Israel we will be targeted. But how can we pull our support of the only democracy in the region? And why should we just in order to pacify violent people who will not give us any guarantee that they will be pacified. I think they will always come up with another reason to "kill the infidels."

 
 I truly do not know the answer Uncle. If I did, I would have a lot more money than I do now. But one thing I think we could do is get off of the notion that our policies and actions globally are beyond reproach and that as Americans we are infoulable. That might mean having to put ourselves in someone elses shoes now and again. Typically, we act in our best interests, as we should, but I often wonder if the persuit of the almighty dollar, regardless of the costs to others, is always worth it. Perhaps we, as a nation, should revisit that ideology. 
 
 But when you write:
 
And why should we just in order to pacify violent people who will not give us any guarantee that they will be pacified. 
 
 
 I couldn't agree more. But the longest journey begins with the first step.
